The assassination of <a href="William%20Hutt%20Curzon%20Wyllie">William Hutt Curzon Wyllie</a> in the hands of <a href="Madanlal%20Dhingra">Madanlal Dhingra</a> was highly publicised and saw increasing surveillance and suppression of Indian nationalism. These were followed by the <a href="Delhi-Lahore%20Conspiracy">1912 attempt</a> on the life of Viceroy of India. Following this, the nucleus of networks formed in <a href="India%20House">India House</a>, the <a href="Anushilan%20Samiti">Anushilan Samiti</a>, nationalists in Punjab, and the nationalism that arose among Indian expatriates and labourers in North America, a different movement began to emerge in the North American <a href="Ghadar%20Party">Ghadar Party</a>, culminating in the <a href="Hindu-German%20Conspiracy">Sedetious conspiracy</a> of World War I led by <a href="Rash%20Behari%20Bose">Rash Behari Bose</a> and <a href="Lala%20Hardayal">Lala Hardayal</a>.
However, the emergence of the Gandhian movement slowly began to absorb the different revolutionary groups. The Bengal "Samiti" moved away from its philosophy of violence in the 1920s, when a number of its members identified closely with the <a href="Indian%20National%20Congress">Congress</a> and Gandhian non-violent movement. Revolutionary nationalist violence saw a resurgence after the collapse of Gandhian non-cooperation movement in 1922. In Bengal, this saw reorganisation of groups linked to the "Samiti" under the leadership of <a href="Surya%20Sen">Surya Sen</a> and <a href="Hem%20Chandra%20Kanungo">Hem Chandra Kanungo</a>. A spate of violence led up to the enactment of the <a href="Bengal%20Criminal%20Law%20Amendment">Bengal Criminal Law Amendment</a> in the early 1920s, which recalled the powers of incarceration and detention of the Defence of India Act. In north India, remnants of Punjab and Bengalee revolutionary organisations reorganised, notably under <a href="Sachindranath%20Sanyal">Sachindranath Sanyal</a>, founding the <a href="Hindustan%20Republican%20Association">Hindustan Republican Association</a> with <a href="Chandrashekhar%20Azad">Chandrashekhar Azad</a> in north India.
The HSRA had strong influences from leftist ideologies. <a href="Hindustan%20Socialist%20Republican%20Association">Hindustan Socialist Republican Association</a> (HSRA) was formed under the leadership of <a href="Chandrasekhar%20Azad">Chandrasekhar Azad</a>. <a href="Kakori%20train%20robbery">Kakori train robbery</a> was done largely by the members of HSRA. A number of Congress leaders from Bengal, especially <a href="Subhash%20Chandra%20Bose">Subhash Chandra Bose</a>, were accused by the British Government of having links with and allowing patronage to the revolutionary organisations during this time. The violence and radical philosophy revived in the 1930s, when revolutionaries of the "Samiti" and the HSRA were involved in the <a href="Chittagong%20armoury%20raid">Chittagong armoury raid</a> and the <a href="Kakori%20conspiracy">Kakori conspiracy</a> and other attempts against the administration in British India and Raj officials. <a href="Sachindra%20Nath%20Sanyal">Sachindra Nath Sanyal</a> mentored revolutionaries in the <a href="Hindustan%20Socialist%20Republican%20Army">Hindustan Socialist Republican Army</a> (HSRA), including Bhagat Singh and <a href="Jatindra%20Nath%20Das">Jatindra Nath Das</a>, among others; including arms training and how to make bombs. <a href="Bhagat%20Singh">Bhagat Singh</a> and <a href="Batukeshwar%20Dutt">Batukeshwar Dutt</a> threw a bomb inside the <a href="Central%20Legislative%20Assembly">Central Legislative Assembly</a> on 8 April 1929 protesting against the passage of the Public Safety Bill and the Trade Disputes Bill while raising slogans of "<a href="Inquilab%20Zindabad">Inquilab Zindabad</a>", though no one was killed or injured in the bomb incident. Bhagat Singh surrendered after the bombing incident and a trial was conducted. Sukhdev and Rajguru were also arrested by police during search operations after the bombing incident. Following the trial (Central Assembly Bomb Case), Bhagat Singh, <a href="Sukhdev">Sukhdev</a> and <a href="Shivaram%20Rajguru">Rajguru</a> were hanged in 1931. <a href="Allama%20Mashriqi">Allama Mashriqi</a> founded <a href="Khaksars">Khaksar Tehreek</a> in order to direct particularly the Muslims towards the self-rule movement. Some of its members left for the Indian National Congress then led by Subhas Chandra Bose, while others identified more closely with <a href="Communism">Communism</a>. The "Jugantar" branch formally dissolved in 1938. On 13 March 1940, <a href="Udham%20Singh">Udham Singh</a> shot <a href="Michael%20O%27Dwyer">Michael O'Dwyer</a> (the last political murder outside India), generally held responsible for the <a href="Amritsar%20Massacre">Amritsar Massacre</a>, in London. However, the revolutionary movement gradually disseminated into the Gandhian movement. As the political scenario changed in the late 1930s — with the mainstream leaders considering several options offered by the British and with religious politics coming into play — revolutionary activities gradually declined. Many past revolutionaries joined mainstream politics by joining <a href="Indian%20National%20Congress">Congress</a> and other parties, especially communist ones, while many of the activists were kept under hold in different jails across the country. Indians who were based in the UK, joined <a href="India%20League">the India League</a> and the <a href="Indian%20Workers%27%20Association">Indian Workers Association</a>, partaking in revolutionary activities in Britain.
Within a short time of its inception, these organisations became the focus of an extensive police and intelligence operations. Operations against "<a href="Anushilan%20Samiti">Anushilan Samiti</a>" saw founding of the <a href="Special%20Branch">Special Branch</a> of <a href="Calcutta%20Police">Calcutta Police</a>. The intelligence operations against India House saw the founding of the <a href="Indian%20Political%20Intelligence%20Office">Indian Political Intelligence Office</a> which later grew to be the Intelligence Bureau in independent India. Heading the intelligence and missions against Ghadarite movement and India revolutionaries was the <a href="MI5%28g%29">MI5(g)</a> section, and at one point involved the <a href="Pinkerton%27s">Pinkerton's</a> detective agency. Notable officers who led the police and intelligence operations against Indian revolutionaries, or were involved in it, at various time included <a href="John%20Arnold%20Wallinger">John Arnold Wallinger</a>, <a href="Sir%20Robert%20Nathan">Sir Robert Nathan</a>, <a href="Sir%20Harold%20Stuart">Sir Harold Stuart</a>, <a href="Vernon%20Kell">Vernon Kell</a>, <a href="Sir%20Charles%20Stevenson-Moore">Sir Charles Stevenson-Moore</a> and <a href="Sir%20Charles%20Tegart">Sir Charles Tegart</a>, as well as <a href="W.%20Somerset%20Maugham">W. Somerset Maugham</a>. Final process of Indian self-rule movement.
In 1937, <a href="Indian%20Provincial%20Elections%2C%201937">provincial elections</a> were held and the Congress came to power in seven of the eleven provinces. This was a strong indicator of the Indian people's support for complete self-rule.
When the Second World War started, <a href="Victor%20Hope%2C%202nd%20Marquess%20of%20Linlithgow">Viceroy Linlithgow</a> unilaterally declared India a belligerent on the side of Britain, without consulting the elected Indian representatives. In opposition to Linlithgow's action, the entire Congress leadership resigned from the provincial and local governments. The Muslims and Sikhs, by contrast, strongly supported the war effort and gained enormous stature in London. Defying Congress, millions of Indians supported the war effort, and indeed the <a href="Indian%20Army%20during%20World%20War%20II">British Indian Army</a> became the largest volunteer force, numbering 2,500,000 men during the war.
Especially during the <a href="Battle%20of%20Britain">Battle of Britain</a> in 1940, Gandhi resisted calls for massive civil disobedience movements that came from within as well as outside his party, stating he did not seek India's self-rule out of the ashes of a destroyed Britain. In 1942, the Congress launched the <a href="Quit%20India">Quit India</a> movement. There was some violence but the Raj cracked down and arrested tens of thousands of Congress leaders, including all the main national and provincial figures. They were not released until the end of the war was in sight in 1945.
The self-rule movement included the <a href="Kakori%20conspiracy">Kakori conspiracy</a> (9 August 1925) led by Indian youth under the leadership of <a href="Pandit%20Ram%20Prasad%20Bismil">Pandit Ram Prasad Bismil</a> and masterminded by <a href="Rajendra%20Lahiri">Rajendra Lahiri</a>; and the <a href="Azad%20Hind">Azad Hind</a> movement, whose main protagonist <a href="Netaji%20Subhas%20Chandra%20Bose">Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose</a> was a former leader of Congress. From its earliest wartime inception, Bose joined the <a href="Axis%20Powers">Axis Powers</a> to fight Britain.
Azad Hind Fauj (Indian National Army).
India's entry into the war was strongly opposed by <a href="Subhas%20Chandra%20Bose">Subhas Chandra Bose</a>, who had been elected President of the Congress in 1938 and 1939, but later resigned owing to differences of opinion with Gandhi. After resignation he formed his own wing separated from the mainstream Congress leadership known as <a href="Forward%20bloc">Forward bloc</a> which was a "loci" focus for ex-congress leaders holding socialist views; however he remained emotionally attached to Congress for the remainder of his life. Bose then founded the <a href="All%20India%20Forward%20Bloc">All India Forward Bloc</a>. In 1940 the British authorities in Calcutta placed Bose under house arrest. However, he escaped and made his way through <a href="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a> to <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a> to seek <a href="Axis%20powers%20of%20World%20War%20II">Hitler and Mussolini's</a> help for raising an army to fight the British. The <a href="Free%20India%20Legion">Free India Legion</a> comprising <a href="Erwin%20Rommel">Erwin Rommel</a>'s Indian POWs was formed. After a dramatic decline in Germany's military fortunes, a German land invasion of India became untenable. Hitler advised Bose to go to Japan where a submarine was arranged to transport Bose, who was ferried to Japanese Southeast Asia, where he formed the <a href="Azad%20Hind%20Government">Azad Hind Government</a>. The Provisional Free Indian Government in exile reorganised the <a href="Indian%20National%20Army">Indian National Army</a> composed of Indian <a href="POW">POW</a>s and volunteer Indian <a href="expatriates">expatriates</a> in South-East Asia, with the help of the Japanese. Its aim was to reach India as a fighting force that would build on public resentment to inspire revolt among Indian soldiers of the Raj.
The INA was to see action against the Allies, including the <a href="British%20Indian%20Army">British Indian Army</a>, in the forests of Arakan, <a href="Burma">Burma</a>, and in <a href="Assam">Assam</a>, laying <a href="Battle%20of%20Imphal">siege to Imphal and Kohima</a> with the <a href="Japanese%2015th%20Army">Japanese 15th Army</a>. During the war, the <a href="Andaman%20and%20Nicobar">Andaman and Nicobar</a> islands <a href="Invasion%20and%20Occupation%20of%20the%20Andaman%20Islands%20during%20World%20War%20II">were captured by the Japanese</a> and handed over by them to the INA.
The INA failed owing to disrupted logistics, poor supplies from the Japanese, and lack of training. The Azad Hind Fauj surrendered unconditionally to the British in Singapore in 1945. In the consensus of scholarly opinion, <a href="Death%20of%20Subhas%20Chandra%20Bose">Subhas Chandra Bose's death</a> occurred from third-degree burns on 18 August 1945 after his overloaded Japanese plane crashed in Japanese-ruled Formosa (now Taiwan).
Trials against members of the INA began in late 1945, and included the infamous joint court-martial of key figures <a href="Shah%20Nawaz%20Khan%20%28general%29">Shah Nawaz Khan</a>, <a href="Prem%20Sahgal">Prem Sahgal</a>, and <a href="Gurbaksh%20Singh%20Dhillon">Gurbaksh Singh Dhillon</a>.
Quit India Movement.
The Quit India Movement "(Bharat Chhodo Andolan)" or the "August Movement" was a <a href="civil%20disobedience">civil disobedience</a> movement in <a href="India">India</a> which commenced on 8 August 1942 in response to <a href="Mohandas%20Karamchand%20Gandhi">Gandhi</a>'s call for immediate self-rule by Indians and against sending Indians to World War II. He asked all teachers to leave their schools, and other Indians to leave their respective jobs and take part in this movement. Due to Gandhi's political influence, his request was followed by a significant proportion of the population. In addition, Congress-led the Quit India Movement to demand the British to leave India and transfer the political power to a representative government.
During the movement, Gandhi and his followers continued to use non-violence against British rule. This movement was where Gandhi gave his famous message, "Do or Die!", and this message spread towards the Indian community. In addition, this movement was addressed directly to women as "disciplined soldiers of Indian freedom" and they had to keep the war for independence to go on (against British rule).
At the outbreak of war, the Congress Party had during the Wardha meeting of the working-committee in September 1939, passed a resolution conditionally supporting the fight against fascism, but were rebuffed when they asked for self-rule in return. In March 1942, faced with an increasingly dissatisfied sub-continent only reluctantly participating in the war, and deteriorations in the war situation in Europe and <a href="South%20East%20Asia">South East Asia</a>, and with growing dissatisfactions among Indian troops- especially in Europe- and among the civilian population in the sub-continent, the British government sent a delegation to India under <a href="Stafford%20Cripps">Stafford Cripps</a>, in what came to be known as the <a href="Cripps%27%20Mission">Cripps' Mission</a>. The purpose of the mission was to negotiate with the Indian National Congress a deal to obtain total co-operation during the war, in return of progressive devolution and distribution of power from the crown and the <a href="Viceroy">Viceroy</a> to elected Indian legislature. However, the talks failed, having failed to address the key demand of a timeframe towards self-government, and of the definition of the powers to be relinquished, essentially portraying an offer of limited dominion-status that was wholly unacceptable to the Indian movement. To force the British Raj to meet its demands and to obtain definitive word on total self-rule, the Congress took the decision to launch the Quit India Movement.
The aim of the movement was to force the British Government to the negotiating table by holding the Allied war effort hostage. The call for determined but <a href="passive%20resistance">passive resistance</a> that signified the certitude that Gandhi foresaw for the movement is best described by his call to "Do or Die", issued on 8 August at the <a href="Gowalia%20Tank">Gowalia Tank</a> Maidan in Bombay, since renamed "August Kranti Maidan" (August Revolution Ground). However, almost the entire Congress leadership, and not merely at the national level, was put into confinement less than 24 hours after Gandhi's speech, and the greater number of the Congress were to spend the rest of the war in jail.
On 8 August 1942, the Quit India resolution was passed at the Mumbai session of the All India Congress Committee (AICC). The draft proposed that if the British did not accede to the demands, a massive Civil Disobedience would be launched. However, it was an extremely controversial decision. At Gowalia Tank, <a href="Mumbai">Mumbai</a>, Gandhi urged Indians to follow non-violent civil disobedience. Gandhi told the masses to act as citizens of a sovereign nation and not to follow the orders of the British. The British, already alarmed by the advance of the Japanese army to the India–Burma border, responded the next day by imprisoning Gandhi at the <a href="Aga%20Khan%20Palace">Aga Khan Palace</a> in <a href="Pune">Pune</a>. The Congress Party's Working Committee, or national leadership was arrested all together and imprisoned at the Ahmednagar Fort. They also banned the party altogether. All the major leaders of the INC were arrested and detained. As the masses were leaderless the protest took a violent turn. Large-scale protests and demonstrations were held all over the country. Workers remained absent en masse and strikes were called. The movement also saw widespread acts of sabotage, Indian under-ground organisation carried out bomb attacks on allied supply convoys, government buildings were set on fire, electricity lines were disconnected and transport and communication lines were severed. The disruptions were under control in a few weeks and had little impact on the war effort. The movement soon became a leaderless act of defiance, with a number of acts that deviated from Gandhi's principle of non-violence. In large parts of the country, the local underground organisations took over the movement. However, by 1943, "Quit India" had petered out.
All the other major parties rejected the Quit India plan, and most cooperated closely with the British, as did the princely states, the civil service, and the police. The <a href="All-India%20Muslim%20League">Muslim League</a> supported the Raj and grew rapidly in membership, and in influence with the British.
There was opposition to the Quit India Movement from several political quarters who were fighting for Indian self-rule. Hindu nationalist parties like the <a href="Hindu%20Mahasabha">Hindu Mahasabha</a> openly opposed the call and boycotted the Quit India Movement. <a href="Vinayak%20Damodar%20Savarkar">Vinayak Damodar Savarkar</a>, the president of the Hindu Mahasabha at that time, even went to the extent of writing a letter titled "Stick to your Posts", in which he instructed Hindu Sabhaites who happened to be "members of municipalities, local bodies, legislatures or those serving in the army...to stick to their posts" across the country, and not to join the Quit India Movement at any cost.
The other Hindu nationalist organisation, and Mahasabha affiliate <a href="Rashtriya%20Swayamsevak%20Sangh">Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh</a> (RSS) had a tradition of keeping aloof from the anti-British Indian self-rule movement since its founding by <a href="K.B.%20Hedgewar">K.B. Hedgewar</a> in 1925. In 1942, the RSS, under <a href="M.S.%20Golwalkar">M.S. Golwalkar</a> completely abstained from joining in the Quit India Movement as well. The Bombay government (British) appreciated the RSS as such, by noting that,
 The Sangh has scrupulously kept itself within the law, and in particular, has refrained from taking part in the disturbances that broke out in August 1942.
The British Government stated that the RSS was not at all supporting any civil disobedience against them, and as such their other political activities(even if objectionable) can be overlooked. Further, the British Government also asserted that at Sangh meetings organised during the times of anti-British movements started and fought by the Indian National Congress,
 Speakers urged the Sangh members to keep aloof from the congress movement and these instructions were generally observed.
 As such, the British government did not crackdown on the RSS and Hindu Mahasabha at all.
The RSS head ("sarsanghchalak") during that time, <a href="M.S.%20Golwalkar">M.S. Golwalkar</a> later openly admitted to the fact that the RSS did not participate in the Quit India Movement. However, such an attitude during the Indian independence movement also led to the Sangh being viewed with distrust and anger, both by the general Indian public, as well as certain members of the organisation itself. In Golwalkar's own words,
In 1942 also, there was a strong sentiment in the hearts of many. At that time too, the routine work of the Sangh continued. Sangh decided not to do anything directly. ‘Sangh is the organisation of inactive people, their talks have no substance’ was the opinion uttered not only by outsiders but also our own "swayamsevaks".
Christmas Island Mutiny.
After two Japanese attacks on <a href="Christmas%20Island">Christmas Island</a> in late February and early March 1942, relations between the British officers and their Indian troops broke down. On the night of 10 March, the Indian troops assisted by Sikh policemen mutinied, killing five British soldiers and imprisoning the remaining 21 Europeans on the island. Later on 31 March, a Japanese fleet arrived at the island and the Indians surrendered.
Royal Indian Navy Revolt.
The <a href="Royal%20Indian%20Navy%20Mutiny">Royal Indian Navy Mutiny</a> encompasses a <a href="strike%20action">total strike</a> and subsequent <a href="mutiny">mutiny</a> by Indian sailors of the Royal Indian Navy on board ship and shore establishments at Bombay (<a href="Mumbai">Mumbai</a>) harbour on 18 February 1946. From the initial flashpoint in Bombay, the mutiny spread and found support throughout <a href="British%20India">British India</a>, from <a href="Karachi">Karachi</a> to <a href="Calcutta">Calcutta</a> and ultimately came to involve 78 ships, 20 shore establishments and 20,000 sailors.
The agitations, mass strikes, demonstrations and consequently support for the mutineers, therefore continued several days even after the mutiny had been called off. Along with this, the assessment may be made that it described in crystal clear terms to the government that the <a href="British%20Indian%20Armed%20forces">British Indian Armed forces</a> could no longer be universally relied upon for support in crisis, and even more it was more likely itself to be the source of the sparks that would ignite trouble in a country fast slipping out of the scenario of political settlement.
Impact of World War II.
<a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> was one of the most significant factors in accelerating Indian independence, and the independence of many British and non-British colonies. In the period 1945–1965, <a href="decolonization">decolonization</a> led to more than three dozen countries getting freedom from their colonial powers. Many factors contributed to the downfall of the British Empire.
When Britain reached out to the US asking for help in the war, the US offered help contingent on Britain decolonizing post-WWII, and that agreement was codified in the <a href="Atlantic%20charter">Atlantic charter</a>. The decolonization of Britain (post-war) also meant that the US and other countries could possibly have access to markets to sell goods that were previously under the British Empire - which were not accessible to them then To bring about these changes, the establishment of the UN following WWII codified sovereignty for nations, and encouraged free trade. The war also forced the British to come to an agreement with Indian leaders to grant them independence if they helped with war efforts since India had one of the largest armies. Also, following WWII, it was untenable for Britain to raise capital on its own to keep its colonies. They needed to rely on America and did so via the <a href="Marshall%20Plan">Marshall Plan</a> to rebuild their country.
Sovereignty and partition of India.
On 3 June <a href="1947">1947</a>, Viscount <a href="Louis%20Mountbatten">Louis Mountbatten</a>, the last British <a href="Governor-General%20of%20India">Governor-General of India</a>, announced the partitioning of British India into <a href="Dominion%20of%20India">India</a> and <a href="Dominion%20of%20Pakistan">Pakistan</a>. With the speedy passage of the <a href="Indian%20Independence%20Act%201947">Indian Independence Act 1947</a>, at 11:57 on <a href="Yom-e-Istiqlal">14 August 1947</a> Pakistan was declared a separate nation. Then at 12:02 A.M., on <a href="Independence%20Day%20%28India%29">15 August 1947</a> India became a sovereign and democratic nation. Eventually, 15 August became Independence Day for India marking the end of British India. Also on 15 August, both Pakistan and India had the right to remain in or remove themselves from the British Commonwealth. But in 1949, India took the decision to remain in the commonwealth.
Violent clashes between Hindus, Sikhs, and Muslims followed. Prime Minister Nehru and deputy prime minister Sardar <a href="Vallabhbhai%20Patel">Vallabhbhai Patel</a> had invited Mountbatten to continue as <a href="Governor%20General%20of%20India">Governor General of India</a> during the period of transition. He was replaced in June 1948 by <a href="Chakravarti%20Rajagopalachari">Chakravarti Rajagopalachari</a>. Patel took on the responsibility for bringing 565 princely states into the Union of India, steering efforts by his "iron fist in a velvet glove" policies, exemplified by the use of military force to integrate <a href="Junagadh">Junagadh</a> and <a href="Hyderabad%20State">Hyderabad State</a> into India (<a href="Operation%20Polo">Operation Polo</a>). On the other hand, Nehru kept the issue of <a href="Kashmir">Kashmir</a> in his hands.
The Constituent Assembly, headed by the prominent lawyer, reformer and Dalit leader, B.R. Ambedkar was tasked with creating the constitution of free India. The Constituent Assembly completed the work of drafting the constitution on 26 November 1949; on 26 January <a href="1950">1950</a>, the <a href="Republic%20of%20India">Republic of India</a> was officially proclaimed. The Constituent Assembly elected <a href="Rajendra%20Prasad">Rajendra Prasad</a> was the first <a href="President%20of%20India">President of India</a>, taking over from Governor General Rajgopalachari. Subsequently, the French ceded <a href="Chandernagore">Chandernagore</a> in 1951, and <a href="Pondicherry%20district">Pondichéry</a> and its remaining Indian colonies by 1954. Indian troops <a href="Indian%20annexation%20of%20Goa">invaded and annexed Goa</a> and Portugal's other <a href="Portuguese%20India">Indian enclaves</a> in 1961, and <a href="Sikkim">Sikkim</a> voted to join the Indian Union in 1975 after the <a href="Nathu%20La%20and%20Cho%20La%20clashes">Indian victory over China</a> in Nathu La and Cho La.
Following self-rule in 1947, India remained in the <a href="Commonwealth%20of%20Nations">Commonwealth of Nations</a>, and <a href="India%E2%80%93United%20Kingdom%20relations">relations between the UK and India</a> have since become friendly. There are many areas in which the two countries seek stronger ties for mutual benefit, and there are also strong cultural and social ties between the two nations. The UK has an ethnic Indian population of over 1.6 million. In 2010, Prime Minister <a href="David%20Cameron">David Cameron</a> described Indian – British relations as a "New <a href="Special%20Relationship">Special Relationship</a>".
